title: Robbie Williams Surpasses The Beatles in UK Album Chart History
summary: Robbie Williams has achieved a significant milestone by surpassing The Beatles to become the artist with the most number one albums in UK chart history. His latest album, Britpop, released recently, marks his 16th number one since beginning his solo career in 1997 with Life Thru A Lens. Williams expressed disbelief and joy, using metaphors like stretching an elastic band to describe his success. He is currently in Paris with his wife, Ayda Field, celebrating modestly with a Coke Zero and a salad, contrasting with his hedonistic past in the 1990s marked by substance abuse and mental health issues. Williams emphasizes his current gratitude and mental well-being, viewing this achievement as a moment to reflect on his journey. The album Britpop nostalgically references his early solo days and the 1990s British music scene, featuring collaborations with artists like Gaz Coombes and Gary Barlow. Reviews have been positive, highlighting the album's energy and thematic connections to his career.

background_read: Robbie Williams rose to fame as a member of Take That, a popular British boy band in the early 1990s. After leaving the group, he launched a successful solo career, known for hits like 'Angels' and 'Rock DJ'. The Beatles, formed in the 1960s, are one of the most influential bands in history, setting many records. The UK album chart, compiled by the Official Charts Company, ranks albums based on sales and streams. Mental health awareness has grown in recent years, with artists like Williams sharing their experiences to reduce stigma. The 1990s Britpop movement included bands like Oasis and Blur, shaping British music culture.
